title-group.article-title: Duration and Timing of In Utero Opioid Exposure and Incidence of Neonatal Withdrawal Syndrome

article-meta.aff: aSocial Science Research Institute, The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA;
bSilberman School of Social Work, Hunter College, City University of New York, New York City, NY;
cSandra Rosenbaum School of Social Work and Institute for Research on Poverty, College of Letters and Sciences, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI;

fn.p: Russell S. Kirby disclosed money was paid to his institution from the Florida Department of Health (partly pass through from the CDC); NIH-NIEHS, and the Department of Defense - project with Baylor College of Medicine. He serves on three foundation boards (ACEREF, 37th Street, and Perinatal Foundation) as well as on the boards of Tampa area market board for March of Dimes and the Wisconsin Association for Perinatal Care. The other authors did not report any potential conflicts of interest.
Each author has confirmed compliance with the journal’s requirements for authorship.

sec.title: Objective:
sec.p: To evaluate the association between prenatal prescription opioid analgesics exposure (duration, timing) and neonatal opioid withdrawal syndrome (NOWS).

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: We conducted an retrospective cohort study of Wisconsin Medicaid-covered singleton live births from 2011–2019. The primary outcome was a NOWS diagnosis in the first 30 days of life. Opioid exposure was identified with any claim for prescription opioid analgesic fills during pregnancy. We measured exposure duration cumulatively in days (1–6, 7–29, 30–89, and ≥ 90) and identified timing as early (first two trimesters only) or late (third trimester, regardless of earlier pregnancy use). We used logistic regression modeling to assess NOWS incidences by exposure duration and timing, with and without propensity score matching.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: Overall, 31,456 (14.3%) out of 220,570 infants were exposed to prescription opioid analgesics prenatally. Among exposed infants, 19,880 (63.2%) had 1–6 days of exposure, 7,694 (24.5%) had 7–29 days, 2,188 (7.0%) had 30–89 days, 1,694 (5.4%) had ≥ 90 days. 15,032 (47.8%) had late exposure. Absolute NOWS incidence among infants with 1–6 days exposure was 7.29 per 1,000 infants (95% CI 6.11–8.48), and incidence increased with longer exposure: 7–29 days (19.63, 95% CI 16.53–22.73); 30–89 days (58.96, 95% CI 49.08–68.84); ≥ 90 days (177.10, 95% CI 158.90–195.29). Absolute NOWS incidence for early and late exposure was 11.26 per 1,000 infants (95% CI 9.65–12.88) and 35.92 per 1,000 infants (95% CI 32.95–38.90) respectively. Adjusting for confounders including timing of exposure, infants exposed for 1–6 days had no increased odds of NOWS compared with unexposed, whereas those exposed ≥ 30 days had increased odds of NOWS (30–89 days: aOR=2.15, 95% CI 1.22–3.79; ≥ 90 days: 2.80, 95% CI 1.36–5.76). Late exposure was associated with elevated odds of NOWS (aOR 1.57, 95% CI 1.25–1.96) when compared with unexposed after adjustment for exposure duration.

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: More than 30 days of prenatal prescription opioid exposure was associated with NOWS regardless of exposure timing. Third trimester opioid exposure, irrespective of exposure duration, was associated with NOWS.

abstract.title: PRÉCIS:
abstract.p: More than 30 days of prenatal opioid exposure was associated with neonatal opioid withdrawal syndrome compared with no exposure, as was exposure late in pregnancy.
